sn55.3:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn55.3:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn55.3:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena dīghāvu upāsako ābādhiko hoti dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
sn55.3:1.2.eng: Now at that time the lay follower Dīghāvu was sick, suffering, gravely ill.

sn55.3:1.3.pli: Atha kho dīghāvu upāsako pitaraṃ jotikaṃ gahapatiṃ āmantesi:
sn55.3:1.3.eng: Then he addressed his father, the householder Jotika,

sn55.3:1.4.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, gahapati, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena bhagavato pāde sirasā vanda:
sn55.3:1.4.eng: “Please, householder, go to the Buddha, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Say to him:

sn55.3:1.5.pli: ‘dīghāvu, bhante, upāsako ābādhiko hoti dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
sn55.3:1.5.eng: ‘Sir, the lay follower Dīghāvu is sick, suffering, gravely ill.

sn55.3:1.6.eng: He bows with his head to your feet.’

sn55.3:1.8.pli: ‘sādhu kira, bhante, bhagavā yena dīghāvussa upāsakassa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā’”ti.
sn55.3:1.8.eng: ‘Sir, please visit him at his home out of sympathy.’”

sn55.3:1.9.pli: “Evaṃ, tātā”ti kho jotiko gahapati dīghāvussa upāsakassa paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho jotiko gahapati bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn55.3:1.9.eng: “Yes, dear,” replied Jotika. He did as Dīghāvu asked.

sn55.3:1.10.pli: “dīghāvu, bhante, upāsako ābādhiko hoti dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.

sn55.3:1.13.pli: ‘sādhu kira, bhante, bhagavā yena dīghāvussa upāsakassa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā’”ti.

sn55.3:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena dīghāvussa upāsakassa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi. Nisajja kho bhagavā dīghāvuṃ upāsakaṃ etadavoca:
sn55.3:2.1.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the home of the lay follower Dīghāvu, sat down on the seat spread out, and said to him,

sn55.3:2.2.pli: “kacci te, dīghāvu, khamanīyaṃ, kacci yāpanīyaṃ? Kacci dukkhā vedanā paṭikkamanti, no abhikkamanti; paṭikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no abhikkamo”ti?
sn55.3:2.2.eng: “I hope you’re keeping well, Dīghāvu; I hope you’re all right. I hope that your pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”

sn55.3:2.3.pli: “Na me, bhante, khamanīyaṃ, na yāpanīyaṃ. Bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti; abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo”ti.
sn55.3:2.3.eng: “Sir, I’m not keeping well, I’m not getting by. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading.”

sn55.3:2.4.eng: “So, Dīghāvu, you should train like this:

sn55.3:2.5.pli: ‘buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato bhavissāmi—itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.
sn55.3:2.5.eng: ‘I will have experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.3:2.8.pli: ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato bhavissāmi akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi’.
sn55.3:2.8.eng: And I will have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.’

sn55.3:3.1.pli: “Yānimāni, bhante, bhagavatā cattāri sotāpattiyaṅgāni desitāni, saṃvijjante dhammā mayi, ahañca tesu dhammesu sandissāmi.
sn55.3:3.1.eng: “Sir, these four factors of stream-entry that were taught by the Buddha are found in me, and I exhibit them.

sn55.3:3.2.pli: Ahañhi, bhante, buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato—itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.
sn55.3:3.2.eng: For I have experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.3:3.5.eng: And I have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.”

sn55.3:3.6.pli: “Tasmātiha tvaṃ, dīghāvu, imesu catūsu sotāpattiyaṅgesu patiṭṭhāya cha vijjābhāgiye dhamme uttari bhāveyyāsi.
sn55.3:3.6.eng: “In that case, Dīghāvu, grounded on these four factors of stream-entry you should further develop these six things that play a part in realization.

sn55.3:3.7.pli: Idha tvaṃ, dīghāvu, sabbasaṅkhāresu aniccānupassī viharāhi, anicce dukkhasaññī, dukkhe anattasaññī pahānasaññī virāgasaññī nirodhasaññīti.
sn55.3:3.7.eng: You should meditate observing the impermanence of all conditions, perceiving suffering in impermanence, perceiving not-self in suffering, perceiving giving up, perceiving fading away, and perceiving cessation.

sn55.3:4.1.pli: “Yeme, bhante, bhagavatā cha vijjābhāgiyā dhammā desitā, saṃvijjante dhammā mayi, ahañca tesu dhammesu sandissāmi.
sn55.3:4.1.eng: “These six things that play a part in realization that were taught by the Buddha are found in me, and I exhibit them.

sn55.3:4.2.pli: Ahañhi, bhante, sabbasaṅkhāresu aniccānupassī viharāmi, anicce dukkhasaññī, dukkhe anattasaññī pahānasaññī virāgasaññī nirodhasaññī.
sn55.3:4.2.eng: For I meditate observing the impermanence of all conditions, perceiving suffering in impermanence, perceiving not-self in suffering, perceiving giving up, perceiving fading away, and perceiving cessation.

sn55.3:4.3.pli: Api ca me, bhante, evaṃ hoti:

sn55.3:4.4.pli: ‘mā hevāyaṃ jotiko gahapati mamaccayena vighātaṃ āpajjī’”ti.
sn55.3:4.4.eng: ‘I hope Jotika doesn’t suffer distress when I’ve gone.’”

sn55.3:4.5.eng: Jotika said, “Dear Dīghāvu, don’t focus on that.

sn55.3:4.6.pli: Iṅgha tvaṃ, tāta dīghāvu, yadeva te bhagavā āha, tadeva tvaṃ sādhukaṃ manasi karohī”ti.
sn55.3:4.6.eng: Come on, dear Dīghāvu, you should closely focus on what the Buddha is saying.”

sn55.3:5.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā dīghāvuṃ upāsakaṃ iminā ovādena ovaditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.
sn55.3:5.1.eng: When the Buddha had given this advice he got up from his seat and left.

sn55.3:5.2.pli: Atha kho dīghāvu upāsako acirapakkantassa bhagavato kālamakāsi.
sn55.3:5.2.eng: Not long after the Buddha left, Dīghāvu passed away.

sn55.3:5.3.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn55.3:5.3.eng: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn55.3:5.4.pli: “yo so, bhante, dīghāvu nāma upāsako bhagavatā saṅkhittena ovādena ovadito so kālaṅkato.
sn55.3:5.4.eng: “Sir, the lay follower named Dīghāvu, who was advised in brief by the Buddha, has passed away.

sn55.3:5.5.eng: Where has he been reborn in his next life?”

sn55.3:5.6.pli: “Paṇḍito, bhikkhave, dīghāvu upāsako, paccapādi dhammassānudhammaṃ, na ca maṃ dhammādhikaraṇaṃ vihesesi.
sn55.3:5.6.eng: “Mendicants, the lay follower Dīghāvu was astute. He practiced in line with the teaching, and did not trouble me about the teachings.

sn55.3:5.7.pli: Dīghāvu, bhikkhave, upāsako pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā opapātiko tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā”ti.
sn55.3:5.7.eng: With the ending of the five lower fetters, he’s been reborn spontaneously, and will become extinguished there, not liable to return from that world.”

sn55.30:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
sn55.30:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

sn55.30:1.2.pli: Atha kho nandako licchavimahāmatto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho nandakaṃ licchavimahāmattaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn55.30:1.2.eng: Then Nandaka the Licchavi chief minister went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:

sn55.30:2.1.pli: “Catūhi kho, nandaka, dhammehi samannāgato ariyasāvako sotāpanno hoti avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo.
sn55.30:2.1.eng: “Nandaka, a noble disciple who has four things is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.

sn55.30:2.3.pli: Idha, nandaka, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—
sn55.30:2.3.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.30:2.4.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.

sn55.30:2.7.pli: ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
sn55.30:2.7.eng: And they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.

sn55.30:2.8.pli: Imehi kho, nandaka, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato ariyasāvako sotāpanno hoti avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo.
sn55.30:2.8.eng: A noble disciple who has these four things is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.

sn55.30:3.1.pli: Imehi ca pana, nandaka, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato ariyasāvako āyunā saṃyutto hoti dibbenapi mānusenapi;
sn55.30:3.1.eng: A noble disciple who has these four things is guaranteed long life, both human and heavenly …

sn55.30:3.5.eng: and sovereignty, both human and heavenly.

sn55.30:3.6.pli: Taṃ kho panāhaṃ, nandaka, nāññassa samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā sutvā vadāmi. Api ca yadeva mayā sāmaṃ ñātaṃ sāmaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sāmaṃ viditaṃ, tadevāhaṃ vadāmī”ti.
sn55.30:3.6.eng: Now, I don’t say this because I’ve heard it from some other ascetic or brahmin. I only say it because I’ve known, seen, and realized it for myself.”

sn55.30:4.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññataro puriso nandakaṃ licchavimahāmattaṃ etadavoca:
sn55.30:4.1.eng: When he had spoken, a certain person said to Nandaka:

sn55.30:4.3.eng: “Enough now, my man, with that exterior bath.

sn55.30:4.4.eng: This interior bathing will do for me, that is,

sn55.31:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurture happiness.

sn55.31:1.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—
sn55.31:1.4.eng: Firstly, a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.31:1.5.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.

sn55.31:1.6.eng: This is the first kind of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurtures happiness.

sn55.31:2.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako dhamme aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—
sn55.31:2.1.eng: Furthermore, a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the teaching …

sn55.31:2.2.pli: svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo …pe… paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhīti.

sn55.31:2.3.eng: This is the second kind of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurtures happiness.

sn55.31:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako saṅghe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—
sn55.31:3.1.eng: Furthermore, a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Saṅgha …

sn55.31:3.2.pli: suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassāti.

sn55.31:3.3.eng: This is the third kind of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurtures happiness.

sn55.31:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
sn55.31:4.1.eng: Furthermore, a noble disciple’s ethical conduct is loved by the noble ones, unbroken, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion.

sn55.31:4.2.eng: This is the fourth kind of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurtures happiness.

sn55.31:4.3.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro puññābhisandā kusalābhisandā sukhassāhārā”ti.
sn55.31:4.3.eng: These are the four kinds of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurture happiness.”

sn55.32:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurture happiness.

sn55.32:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—
sn55.32:1.3.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.32:1.4.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.

sn55.32:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako vigatamalamaccherena cetasā agāraṃ ajjhāvasati muttacāgo payatapāṇi vossaggarato yācayogo dānasaṃvibhāgarato.
sn55.32:3.1.eng: Furthermore, a noble disciple lives at home rid of the stain of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.

sn55.32:3.2.eng: This is the fourth kind of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurtures happiness.

sn55.32:3.3.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro puññābhisandā kusalābhisandā sukhassāhārā”ti.
sn55.32:3.3.eng: These are the four kinds of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurture happiness.”

sn55.33:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurture happiness.

sn55.33:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—
sn55.33:1.3.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.33:1.4.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.

sn55.33:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā.
sn55.33:3.1.eng: Furthermore, a noble disciple is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

sn55.33:3.2.eng: This is the fourth kind of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurtures happiness.

sn55.33:3.3.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro puññābhisandā kusalābhisandā sukhassāhārā”ti.
sn55.33:3.3.eng: These are the four kinds of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness that nurture happiness.”

sn55.34:1.2.pli: “Cattārimāni, bhikkhave, devānaṃ devapadāni avisuddhānaṃ sattānaṃ visuddhiyā apariyodātānaṃ sattānaṃ pariyodapanāya.
sn55.34:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, these four footprints of the gods are in order to purify unpurified beings and cleanse unclean beings.

sn55.34:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—
sn55.34:2.2.eng: Firstly, a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.34:2.3.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.

sn55.34:2.4.pli: Idaṃ paṭhamaṃ devānaṃ devapadaṃ avisuddhānaṃ sattānaṃ visuddhiyā apariyodātānaṃ sattānaṃ pariyodapanāya.
sn55.34:2.4.eng: This is the first footprint of the gods in order to purify unpurified beings and cleanse unclean beings.

sn55.34:3.1.eng: Furthermore, a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the teaching …

sn55.34:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
sn55.34:4.1.eng: Furthermore, a noble disciple’s ethical conduct is loved by the noble ones, unbroken, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion.

sn55.34:4.2.pli: Idaṃ catutthaṃ devānaṃ devapadaṃ avisuddhānaṃ sattānaṃ visuddhiyā apariyodātānaṃ sattānaṃ pariyodapanāya.
sn55.34:4.2.eng: This is the fourth footprint of the gods in order to purify unpurified beings and cleanse unclean beings.

sn55.34:4.3.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, cattāri devānaṃ devapadāni avisuddhānaṃ sattānaṃ visuddhiyā apariyodātānaṃ sattānaṃ pariyodapanāyā”ti.
sn55.34:4.3.eng: These four footprints of the gods are in order to purify unpurified beings and cleanse unclean beings.”

sn55.35:1.1.pli: “Cattārimāni, bhikkhave, devānaṃ devapadāni avisuddhānaṃ sattānaṃ visuddhiyā apariyodātānaṃ sattānaṃ pariyodapanāya.
sn55.35:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these four footprints of the gods are in order to purify unpurified beings and cleanse unclean beings.

sn55.35:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—
sn55.35:2.2.eng: Firstly, a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha:

sn55.35:2.3.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.
sn55.35:2.3.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

sn55.35:2.5.eng: ‘What now is the footprint of the gods?’

sn55.35:2.7.eng: ‘I hear that these days the gods consider non-harming to be supreme.

sn55.35:2.8.pli: Na ca kho panāhaṃ kiñci byābādhemi tasaṃ vā thāvaraṃ vā.
sn55.35:2.8.eng: But I don’t hurt any creature firm or frail.

sn55.35:2.9.eng: I definitely live in possession of a footprint of the gods.’

sn55.35:2.10.pli: Idaṃ paṭhamaṃ devānaṃ devapadaṃ avisuddhānaṃ sattānaṃ visuddhiyā apariyodātānaṃ sattānaṃ pariyodapanāya.
sn55.35:2.10.eng: This is the first footprint of the gods in order to purify unpurified beings and cleanse unclean beings.

sn55.35:3.1.eng: Furthermore, a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the teaching …

sn55.35:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
sn55.35:4.1.eng: Furthermore, a noble disciple’s ethical conduct is loved by the noble ones, unbroken, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion.

sn55.35:4.3.eng: ‘What now is the footprint of the gods?’

sn55.35:4.5.eng: ‘I hear that these days the gods consider non-harming to be supreme.

sn55.35:4.6.pli: Na kho panāhaṃ kiñci byābādhemi tasaṃ vā thāvaraṃ vā.
sn55.35:4.6.eng: But I don’t hurt any creature firm or frail.

sn55.35:4.7.eng: I definitely live in possession of a footprint of the gods.’

sn55.35:4.8.pli: Idaṃ catutthaṃ devānaṃ devapadaṃ avisuddhānaṃ sattānaṃ visuddhiyā apariyodātānaṃ sattānaṃ pariyodapanāya.
sn55.35:4.8.eng: This is the fourth footprint of the gods in order to purify unpurified beings and cleanse unclean beings.

sn55.35:4.9.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, cattāri devānaṃ devapadāni avisuddhānaṃ sattānaṃ visuddhiyā apariyodātānaṃ sattānaṃ pariyodapanāyā”ti.
sn55.35:4.9.eng: These four footprints of the gods are in order to purify unpurified beings and cleanse unclean beings.”

sn55.36:1.1.pli: “Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgataṃ attamanā devā sabhāgataṃ kathenti.
sn55.36:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when someone has four things the gods are pleased and speak of what they have in common.

sn55.36:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—
sn55.36:1.3.eng: Firstly, a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.36:1.4.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.

sn55.36:1.5.pli: Yā tā devatā buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgatā ito cutā tatrūpapannā tāsaṃ evaṃ hoti:
sn55.36:1.5.eng: There are deities with experiential confidence in the Buddha who passed away from here and were reborn there. They think:

sn55.36:1.6.pli: ‘yathārūpena kho mayaṃ buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgatā tato cutā idhūpapannā, ariyasāvakopi tathārūpena buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato ehīti devānaṃ santike’ti.
sn55.36:1.6.eng: ‘Having such experiential confidence in the Buddha, we passed away from there and were reborn here. That noble disciple possesses the same kind of experiential confidence in the Buddha, so they will come into the presence of the gods.’

sn55.36:2.1.eng: Furthermore, a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the teaching …

sn55.36:2.3.pli: ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
sn55.36:2.3.eng: And they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.

sn55.36:2.4.pli: Yā tā devatā ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgatā ito cutā tatrūpapannā tāsaṃ evaṃ hoti:
sn55.36:2.4.eng: There are deities with the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones who passed away from here and were reborn there. They think:

sn55.36:2.5.pli: ‘yathārūpehi kho mayaṃ ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgatā tato cutā idhūpapannā, ariyasāvakopi tathārūpehi ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato ehīti devānaṃ santike’ti.
sn55.36:2.5.eng: ‘Having such ethical conduct loved by the noble ones, we passed away from there and were reborn here. That noble disciple possesses the same kind of ethical conduct loved by the noble ones, so they will come into the presence of the gods.’

sn55.36:2.6.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgataṃ attamanā devā sabhāgataṃ kathentī”ti.
sn55.36:2.6.eng: When someone has four things the gods are pleased and speak of what they have in common.”

sn55.37:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmiṃ nigrodhārāme.
sn55.37:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.

sn55.37:1.2.pli: Atha kho mahānāmo sakko yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho mahānāmo sakko bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn55.37:1.2.eng: Then Mahānāma the Sakyan went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn55.37:2.1.eng: “Sir, how is a lay follower defined?”

sn55.37:2.2.pli: “Yato kho, mahānāma, buddhaṃ saraṇaṃ gato hoti, dhammaṃ saraṇaṃ gato hoti, saṅghaṃ saraṇaṃ gato hoti—
sn55.37:2.2.eng: “Mahānāma, when you’ve gone for refuge to the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha,

sn55.37:2.3.eng: you’re considered to be a lay follower.”

sn55.37:3.1.eng: “But how is an ethical lay follower defined?”

sn55.37:3.2.pli: “Yato kho, mahānāma, upāsako pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti, kāmesumicchācārā paṭivirato hoti, musāvādā paṭivirato hoti, surāmerayamajjappamādaṭṭhānā paṭivirato hoti—
sn55.37:3.2.eng: “When a lay follower doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit sexual misconduct, lie, or consume beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants,

sn55.37:3.3.pli: ettāvatā kho, mahānāma, upāsako sīlasampanno hotī”ti.
sn55.37:3.3.eng: they’re considered to be an ethical lay follower.”

sn55.37:4.1.eng: “But how is a faithful lay follower defined?”

sn55.37:4.2.pli: “Idha, mahānāma, upāsako saddho hoti, saddahati tathāgatassa bodhiṃ—
sn55.37:4.2.eng: “It’s when a lay follower has faith in the Realized One’s awakening:

sn55.37:4.3.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.
sn55.37:4.3.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

sn55.37:4.4.pli: Ettāvatā kho, mahānāma, upāsako saddhāsampanno hotī”ti.
sn55.37:4.4.eng: Then they’re considered to be a faithful lay follower.”

sn55.37:5.1.eng: “But how is a generous lay follower defined?”

sn55.37:5.2.pli: “Idha, mahānāma, upāsako vigatamalamaccherena cetasā agāraṃ ajjhāvasati muttacāgo payatapāṇi vossaggarato yācayogo dānasaṃvibhāgarato—
sn55.37:5.2.eng: “It’s when a lay follower lives at home rid of the stain of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.

sn55.37:5.3.pli: ettāvatā kho, mahānāma, upāsako cāgasampanno hotī”ti.
sn55.37:5.3.eng: Then they’re considered to be a generous lay follower.”

sn55.37:6.1.eng: “But how is a wise lay follower defined?”

sn55.37:6.2.pli: “Idha, mahānāma, upāsako paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā—
sn55.37:6.2.eng: “It’s when a lay follower is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

sn55.37:6.3.pli: ettāvatā kho, mahānāma, upāsako paññāsampanno hotī”ti.
sn55.37:6.3.eng: Then they’re considered to be a wise lay follower.”

sn55.38:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, uparipabbate thullaphusitake deve vassante taṃ udakaṃ yathāninnaṃ pavattamānaṃ pabbatakandarapadarasākhā paripūreti, pabbatakandarapadarasākhā paripūrā kusobbhe paripūrenti, kusobbhā paripūrā mahāsobbhe paripūrenti, mahāsobbhā paripūrā kunnadiyo paripūrenti, kunnadiyo paripūrā mahānadiyo paripūrenti, mahānadiyo paripūrā mahāsamuddaṃ paripūrenti;
sn55.38:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, suppose the heavens rain heavily on a mountain top, and the water flows downhill to fill the hollows, crevices, and creeks. As they become full, they fill up the pools. The pools fill up the lakes, the lakes fill up the streams, and the streams fill up the rivers. And as the rivers become full, they fill up the ocean.

sn55.38:1.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa yo ca buddhe aveccappasādo, yo ca dhamme aveccappasādo, yo ca saṅghe aveccappasādo, yāni ca ariyakantāni sīlāni—
sn55.38:1.2.eng: In the same way, a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and the ethics loved by the noble ones.

sn55.38:1.3.pli: ime dhammā sandamānā pāraṃ gantvā āsavānaṃ khayāya saṃvattantī”ti.
sn55.38:1.3.eng: These things flow onwards; and, after crossing to the far shore, they lead to the ending of defilements.”

sn55.39:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmiṃ nigrodhārāme.
sn55.39:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.

sn55.39:1.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena kāḷigodhāya sākiyāniyā nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
sn55.39:1.2.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the home of Kāḷigodhā the Sakyan lady, where he sat on the seat spread out.

sn55.39:1.3.pli: Atha kho kāḷigodhā sākiyānī yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho kāḷigodhaṃ sākiyāniṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn55.39:1.3.eng: Then Kāḷigodhā went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to her:

sn55.39:2.1.pli: “Catūhi kho, godhe, dhammehi samannāgatā ariyasāvikā sotāpannā hoti avinipātadhammā niyatā sambodhiparāyaṇā.
sn55.39:2.1.eng: “Godhā, a female noble disciple who has four things is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.

sn55.39:2.3.pli: Idha, godhe, ariyasāvikā buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgatā hoti—
sn55.39:2.3.eng: It’s when a female noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.39:2.4.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.

sn55.39:2.7.pli: vigatamalamaccherena cetasā agāraṃ ajjhāvasati muttacāgā payatapāṇinī vossaggaratā yācayogā dānasaṃvibhāgaratā.
sn55.39:2.7.eng: And she lives at home rid of the stain of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.

sn55.39:2.8.pli: Imehi kho, godhe, catūhi dhammehi samannāgatā ariyasāvikā sotāpannā hoti avinipātadhammā niyatā sambodhiparāyaṇā”ti.
sn55.39:2.8.eng: A female noble disciple who has these four things is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”

sn55.39:3.1.pli: “Yānimāni, bhante, bhagavatā cattāri sotāpattiyaṅgāni desitāni, saṃvijjante dhammā mayi, ahañca tesu dhammesu sandissāmi.
sn55.39:3.1.eng: “Sir, these four factors of stream-entry that were taught by the Buddha are found in me, and I exhibit them.

sn55.39:3.2.eng: For I have experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.39:3.3.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.

sn55.39:3.6.pli: yaṃ kho pana kiñci kule deyyadhammaṃ sabbaṃ taṃ appaṭivibhattaṃ sīlavantehi kalyāṇadhammehī”ti.
sn55.39:3.6.eng: And I share without reservation all the gifts available to give in our family with those who are ethical and of good character.”

sn55.39:3.8.eng: You have declared the fruit of stream-entry.”

sn55.4:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ca sāriputto āyasmā ca ānando sāvatthiyaṃ viharanti jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn55.4:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Sāriputta was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn55.4:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:
sn55.4:1.2.eng: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Ānanda came out of retreat … and said to Sāriputta:

sn55.4:1.3.pli: “katinaṃ nu kho, āvuso sāriputta, dhammānaṃ samannāgamanahetu evamayaṃ pajā bhagavatā byākatā sotāpannā avinipātadhammā niyatā sambodhiparāyaṇā”ti?
sn55.4:1.3.eng: “Reverend, how many things do people have to possess in order for the Buddha to declare that they’re a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening?”

sn55.4:1.4.pli: “Catunnaṃ kho, āvuso, dhammānaṃ samannāgamanahetu evamayaṃ pajā bhagavatā byākatā sotāpannā avinipātadhammā niyatā sambodhiparāyaṇā.
sn55.4:1.4.eng: “Reverend, people have to possess four things in order for the Buddha to declare that they’re a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.

sn55.4:2.2.pli: Idhāvuso, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti—
sn55.4:2.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha …

sn55.4:2.3.pli: itipi so bhagavā …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavāti.

sn55.4:2.6.pli: ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi …pe… samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
sn55.4:2.6.eng: And they have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.

sn55.4:2.7.pli: Imesaṃ kho, āvuso, catunnaṃ dhammānaṃ samannāgamanahetu evamayaṃ pajā bhagavatā byākatā sotāpannā avinipātadhammā niyatā sambodhiparāyaṇā”ti.
sn55.4:2.7.eng: People have to possess these four things in order for the Buddha to declare that they’re a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”
